273. Heacock, Gertie (Mrs. S.)
What did pioneer Canadian pioneers eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Heacock
Address Houghton Ranch
Birthplace Hurstville, Ill., U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Outlook, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Edmunds, Mo., U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Seven
How far was it to your nearest store? 25 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? We stayed at Outlook for a year and a half then moved to our homestead W.F. & S. 24-28-13 fifteen miles from where we are living now; the R.R. station was built and circled us so that it was 13½ to Logan & 12 to Lelandia was our nearest town 45 miles.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Graham
and Robin Hood were very favorite
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually got 100 lbs in the fall
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 3.50 to 3.00 each
How much did you use Graham flour? Always had on hand enough to last
Whole wheat flour? I did not use for it the
Was flour milled locally? Yes, far away? No, that year? 1911
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 50
What other grain products did you use? ...........................................
Cornmeal? 50 lbs Whole wheat? Farine?
Other? ..................................................................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? ...........................................................................
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

My family got sugar & flour at one time.

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? $4 or $5 a hundred.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $4 or $5 a hundred.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Budweiser.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb. each.

At what price? $1.40.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had cows.

Butter? Yes, we also had eggs.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, how? Trained various ways, wrapped in paper towels.

Did you make butter? Yes, cheese? Yes, cottage cheese.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Cured hogs and chickens.

How did you get fresh meat? The R.R. came in soon after 1873. I believe we took over a county L.O. Right it for 3-3 years so need to turn out a week.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? By salting and curing it.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? In later years.

If so what year was it organized? Not sure.

Did you use game? Yes, what kinds? Pigeon, ducks and geese. Did have a few deer & rabbits.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? There was some near us. In later years we used to send.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? For some.

Kinds? White fish, tubbed, junk fish.

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? green tea. At what price? 50¢ per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Blue Ribbon. Price? $1.00 per lb.

What other beverages were used? lots of milk.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? Could not get them.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter? Some years we had vegetables ready curled.

Potatoes. Cabbage. Carrots. Onions.

Turnips. Beets.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 2 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Both ways.

What weight? 11 lbs.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Both ways.

What was the price of prunes? 10¢ per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? All kinds.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons?

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? I canned fruit every year.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? Never canned much.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? About 1915.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent? A lot...a great deal.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

16. **SNAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the snappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

I do not remember

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: coffee, pancakes, meat, syrup, juice, cream & sugar
Dinner: meat, potatoes, vegetable, bread & butter, tea
and with dessert of some kind
Supper: bread, butter, potatoes, vegetable, fruit & cake

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Our first dinner we were invited to and we had a wonderful meal—a real English dinner—turkey and everything that went with it as I said if you had the money you could buy plenty of everything and crops were good there and money plenty.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, I did not get out of groceries as much as I do now and the store is so close away, the only trouble was once time the store was empty that did not bother us for at that time my husband did not use it but my neighbors did and among the P.C. many a lot of work we bring to them you could be out of anything else and there was no need.
Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time.

Breakfast: coffee, tea, sugar, cream, butter, toast, eggs, bacon, sausage

Dinner: meat, potatoes, vegetables, bread, butter, tea

Supper: bread, butter, potatoes, vegetables, fruit, cake

16. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Canada?

Our first dinner was served at the time. Didn't share presents and there was no tree.

It was a wonderful meal, a real English dinner. Turkey and everything that went with it was said.

If you had the money, you could buy plenty of everything and enjoy your good times and company.

18. What did you get out of poverty so much as I do own and the other is to be placed away. The only trouble was that there the tobacco got empty that did not bother us for at that time every husband did not use it.

Get any supplies and buying the P.C., owning a lot of it we bring to them you could be out of anything else and there was no trouble.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Well the outstanding difference is when I first moved on the homestead only 3 children came with me two girls went away to school they came back except spring later we had three more so there was lots more to do I even raised 3 of my brothers children took care of my aged mother took care of the sick laid away the dead dressed the new born babies sometimes on the even no one died that same day.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I don't suppose I bought 10 loaves of bread up until 10 years ago our cookies cakes were never on any grocery list I made everything myself done all on our own raising I raised a family of eight and they are living today never had but one in the hospital until they left home.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I bought plenty of good staple articles and I could get a good meal at any time.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

I don't suppose I thought to learn of bread up until 10 years ago an earthen cake was never at any grocery list. I make every thing myself time all on own owning I raised a family of eight and they are doing today there still two one in the hospital until they left home.
